bibl.title: Notes on Dinner for John J. Moran, by Atcheson Laughlin Hench, October 23, 1940

div1.p: Atcheson Hench describes the setting, guests, conversations, and presentations at a dinner given in honor of Moran at which Kean described the yellow fever experiments and Moran answered questions from the guests.

div1.head: Notes on Dinner for John J. Moran, by Atcheson Laughlin Hench, October 23, 1940
div1.p:
This is a copy of notes I made October 23, 1940 after I came home from
a dinner given to Mr. John J. Moran, one of Walter Reed's assistants in the discovery
of the cause of yellow fever. The dinner was given by the doctors of the University
of Virginia Medical School at Mrs. Beauchamp's home Myhill, east of town. I was
invited because of my brother Phil's connection with the study of the history of the
discovery. I made the original notes immediately after I came home.
A. L. Hench

Jordan, dean of the Medical School, was
the introducer. With him as guests were
Mr. Moraln; General Kean, from Washington;
Mr. Clemons, U. Va. librarian; General
Kean's son who drove his father (quite aged)
up from Richmond (Young Kean was on our
chemistry faculty here some years ago.); and
myself.

During the meal Mr. Moran mentioned to Jordan or me many things that crossed
his mind as we talked with him.

He said that Cubans do not recognize Reed's part in the experiments; they
give the credit to Agramonte.

Mrs. Moran is with him. She lived in New York during the World War in
1918-19 when he was in France and there picked up English, though she is still shy
2
about talking to people in English the first few minutes of each conversation.
She never sleeps well when he is away from home. “I tell her,” he said, “not to be
afraid. Nothing ever happens to an Irishman.” (Mrs. Jordan took care of Mrs. Moran
and had a small supper party for her during their stay.)

He spoke of an honor trial here at the University (in 1902?) while he was
a student. It was of a boy by the name of Page. He refused to leave the town, but
hired a criminal lawyer instead. The students had nine of the faculty as jury. A
holiday was declared and he was tried in Cabell Hall before the whole student body.

His health prevents him from eating raw things like celery, or steak or
too much coffee, or any liquor. He never feels the desire for liquor anymore at
all, now that he has given it up.

He praised Phil for his painstaking accuracy in tracing things. He thought
I was Phil's younger brother. He praised Mary for letting Phil wear himself out even
on vacation in Cuba, knowing that she couldn't stop him.

After dinner Jordan rose and spoke about as follows: "We are here tonight
to honor Mr. Moran, one of the persons used by Walter Reed in his yellow fever studies.
He is a shy man and is the last one to talk about himself. (Jordan had earlier told
me that repeatedly all afternoon Moran had said he could not make a speech.) But he
did a heroic thing and even though he himself does not consider himself a hero, he is
so to us. He was Sergeant O'Hara in the play “Yellow Jack” and as such was an
inspiration to thousands of children all over America. He is a man who, when the
government gave each member of the group of those who submitted themselves to
experimentation a gift of $200, refused the gift. He was a medical student here in
1902 (?) for a term but was forced by poverty to leave.

“We are proud to have here also General Kean, a close friend of Walter Reed,
who will tell of the experiments of which Mr. Moran was a part. General Kean.”
(His name is pronounced as if it were Kane.)

General Kean began speaking standing up but soon said, “May I speak sitting
down? I'm a bit weak in my pins.” (His son told me later that he has a ticklish
heart. I think he is about 80 years old.)

Kean reviewed the story of the search for the cause of yellow fever. As
well as I can remember his resumé of it, it went thus: He spoke of a Dr. Agramonte
who had been working on a germ which later turned out to be a hog cholera germ, not
that of yellow fever. He spoke then of a Dr. Finley who began suspecting one of the
varieties of mosquiot, of Reed's being appointed to come down and see if he could find
out anything, of the appointment of a board of Reed, Finley (?) and Vaughan. He told
the story of Dr. Lazear's being bitten and questioned whether the accurate scientist
Lazear would have allowed a stray mosquito to bit him by accident while applying an
experimental mosquito to another one's arm. He said he believes Phil's suspicion that
Lazear feared that he would lose the small insurance he had for his family if the
insurance company knew that he had allowed an experimental mosquito to bit him and so
he told the other story. Kean believes Phil is right. The test-tube method of
application was the one used by Reed.

He told the story of the building of two shacks, one for positive proof,
one for negative proof. Dr. Cooke (now county health officer of Rockingham County,
Virginia) was in the negative shack, full of the bed clothing, towels with black
vomit from yellow fever patients, etc. They slept on beds, wrapped towels around
their necks to get yellow fever; for the belief was then that the clothing and
bedding gave the disease (All clothing was usually burned.) Cooke and others never
got the disease.

The other shack was split in half and a mosquito screen was put up; the
air in the building was the same. In the infective half of this shack the experimented-
on persons were introduced. First, I think he said, some Spanish immigrants were used.
They were poor and they were sure to get yellow fever anyway. So the idea was put
forward that they be experimented on. When four or five of them got the fever, the
rest backed out. Then the call came for Americans. Moran had been hospital assistant
and offered; Kissinger too.

For a while the experimenting was secret. Then Kean went to General Wood with
Reed and asked if he would not let the experimenting be brought out into the light and
allot $10,000 for it. He said he would and he would also allot a second $10,000 if
necessary.

He told of Reed's coming up to Indianapolis to a convention of the Public
Health Commission (?) and reading a paper on yellow fever which because of its clarity
and logic just knocked all others' ideas out.

He told of Vaughan's (?) saving the papers of Dr. Finley (?) in which were
invaluable records of experimentation, from being thrown away after his death; and of
their publication.
He mentioned a Major Michie associated with Walter Reed.

He spoke of his telling Reed not to subject the lives of his medical board
to the danger of death. They were needed to prove the experiment.

Someone, possibly Jordan (or Moran himself), told that after the Cuban
affair was over Moran came with $600 and some poker money to New York with Kissinger
and they stopped at a cheap Mills Hotel, one of a chain of cheap hotels. Moran went
to New Jersey and got a job as a soda fountain man and drug assistant (I don't remember
just when this was told during the dinner.)

Dr. Jordan, after General Kean's account, introduced Mr. Moran and said
that he was unable to make a speech but would answer questions put to him by the
group.
Were you scared? “No, I wasn't.”

What temperature did you have? He answered by telling the story of his
being bitten. He went into the infective room with infected mosquitoes. He lay
down on a hospital cot with his clothes off. He was first bitten by about seven
mosquitoes. He watched them in a mirror put above him for the purpose. Later in the
day he was bitten by four more. On Christmas day he began getting temperature. He had
kept a chart of temperature and pulse on a sheet. (He added parenthetically that he
had regularly done that before in the medical corps he belonged to.) When he got
temperature, he had been told to take it every hour. On Christmas day he wanted to
win a bet with a man that he would eat Christmas dinner with his fellow soldiers. He
had eaten a hearty breakfast. His temperature had come later in the morning. At
dinner time he was weak but he wanted to win the bet. So he went to mess--grand meal
of turkey, cranberries and plum-duff (plum pudding). He ate a little bit, knowing
that much eating was very harmful if you had fever. Major Reed had not come in in the
morning; he did not come in until three o'clock in the afternoon. He asked about
Moran's temperature, was shown the chart, and was a very happy man. “I was very useless
for several days. I didn't care about what happened.”

Question: What was Reed like personally? “The gentlest, kindest man I
ever knew. He was what I would imagine the finest product of the South could produce,
a fine Virginian. He wouldn't hurt a fly, as we say--unless it was a scientific fly.”

That suggested an experience which he then told: "May I tell about malaria
at Culebra in 1904? I'd had malaria off and on for some years. The doctor there had
figured out a way to make the Jamaica natives take quinine, by mixing it with rum.
He said he'd soak the malaria out of me. He gave me a supply of rum enough for six
6
months. I asked for another and got enough to last for a year (?) longer.

“In Cuba I had malaria and was three times mistaken for having yellow
fever. The nurses wouldn't believe I was immune. It took General Gorgas every time
to get me removed to the malaria ward.”

He then told a story of an officer who did not like him, but the officer
could not court martial him. Moran got a leave of absence and went to General Kean's
army office clerk and told him. In a week he was quietly transferred.

Dr. Jordan read a letter from Dr. Cooke (Lexington, Virginia--the man
who was mentioned earlier as having been among those who went into the infected-
clothing shack) saying that he was immunizing for two days and could not come over
to the dinner.

After the dinner Mr. Moran showed his Congressional medal that he got as
a member of the Walter Reed experimental group.

During his story about the yellow fever experiments, Mr. Moran said that
he did not bluster before Major Reed or one of the other doctors as he was pictured
in the movie.

This was a well-planned occasion. General Kean's account took about fifty
minutes and nicely fitted Moran into the story as a whole. Moran talked between thirty
and forty minutes. The whole occasion was very interesting, with Mr. Moran's story
coming as the climax. And I was most appreciative of Doctor Jordan's putting me next
to Mr. Moran
